awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Mid-IR Photonic Funnels: Coupling, emitting, and re-shaping mid-IR photons in the nano-world
awd_abstract_narration:
Progress in the fields of materials science, nanotechnology, healthcare, and communications all require precise control and understanding of light interaction with nanoscale objects. Unfortunately, the phenomenon known as the diffraction limit prevents focusing of light to areas smaller than approximately half the wavelength of the light. For thermal (mid-infrared) radiation, the diffraction limit-scale is roughly five microns, much larger than 10-100’s-nanometer size of semiconductor electronic components, viruses, and other objects of interest. In this collaborative research the investigators develop novel structures, photonic funnels, that eliminate the diffraction limit and efficiently guide the optical signals between free space and nano-scale areas. Theoretically, the investigators develop equations and computer codes to model propagation of light through the funnels, as well as the emission of light by nanoscale objects positioned within, and in proximity to, the funnels. Experimentally, the researchers develop procedures to fabricate the funnels, integrate light emitters, and analyze light propagation through, and from, these structures. The exploration and development of these novel composite materials have the potential to open new avenues in high-resolution probing of biological, electronic, and optical structures, and in engineering optical interactions with these structures. In addition, the investigators plan for outreach and educational activities aimed at both high-school and college-level students, as well as personnel exchange and training across the disciplines.

This collaborative project aims to address one of the fundamental limits of light-matter interaction, the diffraction limit. The research team utilizes recently developed composite optical materials with highly doped plasmonic inclusions, hyperbolic metamaterials, and develops tools for the design, fabrication, and analysis of conical structures with hyperbolic cores, photonic funnels, in the important mid-infrared frequency range. The strong dielectric anisotropy of hyperbolic materials postpones the onset of the diffraction limit inside the funnels and thus enables propagation of light between micro- and nano-scales. The research team analyzes, theoretically and experimentally, light-matter interaction inside, and in close proximity to, the photonic funnels. Specifically, the team develops theoretical tools capable of accurate modelling of light generation from within, and in the near field of, the funnels, as well as of light propagation through the funnels. In parallel, the team develops fabrication and characterization procedures to accurately control the geometry of the funnels and to understand their optical response. The collaborative feedback within the team enables comprehensive development of a novel material platform offering unique opportunities for light manipulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to guide, focus, and extract light are the driving force behind sensing, communications, materials development, and other technologies that are embedded into our modern life. In this collaborative project the teams from University of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) and University of Texas Austin (UT) aimed to analyze, optimize, and realize a new class of nanostructured materials, photonic funnels, for efficient confinement and extraction of mid-infrared light to and from nanoscale areas. From the design standpoint, photonic funnels represent conical structures with a multi-layer “metamaterial” core, with iterative undoped and highly doped layers. Depending on the operating wavelength, the combination of all-semiconducting-layers behaves as either conventional transparent dielectric or as a strongly-anisotropic (hyperbolic) material that combines the properties of transparent dielectrics and reflective metals, directing the flow of light into well-defined “critical angle” directions.

Over the course of the program, the UT team focused on perfecting recipes for fabricating the photonic funnels with desired dimensions and optical properties, while the UML team focused on developing theoretical tools to understand the interaction of light with photonic funnels, and using these tools to optimize the structures, and to model the optical behavior of the funnels fabricated by UT team [Fig.1]. We have demonstrated high-performance confinement of mid-infrared light to wavelength/25-spatial areas, and theoretically predicted high-performance extraction of light from deep subwavelength areas by the same structures. The dynamics of ultrafast pulses were analyzed.

 The toolkit developed by UML was used to explore the utility of multilayered materials to focus angle-momentum-carrying beams at visible frequencies, resulting in realization of optical hypergratings, and achieving deep subwavelength focusing of angular momentum-carrying beams and forming optical skyrmions [Fig.2].  

 In separate but related efforts, UML team has developed machine learning tools to both analyze objects with sub-wavelength resolution and to predict distribution of electromagnetic fields within metamaterials. The latter effort provides a recipe for embedding scientific knowledge into machine learning processes to improve accuracy and generalizability of predictions [Fig.3].

 

 

The program has resulted in 3 publications in professional media, with three more publication under review/in preparation, as well as numerous invited and contributed presentations.

 

At UML, the program contributed to MS research of two students (one – physics and one – computer science) and Ph.D. research of two other graduate students. At UT the program funded one doctoral student who will be graduating with his PhD in late 2025.  Apart from educational and research activities, the teams have participated in a number of outreach events, promoting science and enhancing Physics education among high- and middle-school students and teachers.
